channel.title: The only way to fly
channel.description:
A series about the safety aspects of commercial airlines and commercial air transport in the United States.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

item.title: Program 5 of 5
item.description: For the final program in the series we return to the question with which it began five weeks ago: how safe is safe? Future of aviation. Guests: George A. Van Epps, federal supervisory air safety investigator in New York; and Edward Slattery, National Transportation Safety Board, Washington, D.C.
item.dc:creator: Baron, Edward
item.dc:subject: U.S. Politics

item.title: Program 1 of 5: Regulations and standards in the airline industry.
item.description: A.J. Behrens of the Flight Standards Division, Federal Aviation Administration, discusses the system worthiness analysis, engineering manufacturing, aircraft manufacturing management, maintenance, and operations branches of his division.
item.dc:creator: Baron, Edward
item.dc:subject: U.S. Politics

item.title: Program 2 of 5
item.description: A conversation with Edwin L. Shoop, the public affairs officer of the National Aviation Facilities Experimental Center located at the municipal airport of Atlantic City, New Jersey. The center conducts research and evaluation of FAA procedures for new safety devices and then reports their results to FAA headquarters, where the flight standard service may write the new product or procedure into the regulations.
item.dc:creator: Baron, Edward
item.dc:subject: U.S. Politics

item.title: Program 4 of 5
item.description: Modern airborn collision avoidance systems; also medical research in aviation with Dr. Stanley Mohler of the Office of Aviation Medicine, Washington, D.C.
item.dc:creator: Baron, Edward
item.dc:subject: U.S. Politics

item.title: Program 3 of 5
item.description: A very important area of aviation safety research is in the field of air traffic control, through the use of improved radar systems. Some of the systems developed and tested are now in use at the New York Air Route Traffic Control Center. Stanley Lowell, facility analysis officer, talks about the operations of the Center.
item.dc:creator: Baron, Edward
item.dc:subject: U.S. Politics
